dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty-one point eight trillion dollars in liquidity from the Fed, ECB, BOJ, and Bank of England—that's the size of the entire U.S. economy!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty-one point eight trillion dollars in liquidity from the Fed, E C B, B O J, and Bank of England-that's the size of the entire U.S. economy!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's just the start, right? The article mentions this might be setting us up for a lost decade in global growth, worse than people think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's just the start, right? The article mentions this might be setting us up for a lost decade in global growth, worse than people think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That may be just the start, as the odds of new outbreaks threaten to pulverize demand from China to Brazil. Its also a reason to worry about a lost decade for global growth that sets back living standards more than economists and investors realize.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they bring up Japan as a cautionary tale—Haruhiko Kuroda at the BOJ has been fighting deflation for years with massive easing, but it's not really turning things around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they bring up Japan as a cautionary tale-Haruhiko Kuroda at the B O J has been fighting deflation for years with massive easing, but it's not really turning things around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though the BOJ made some progress since 2013 generating upward price pressures, the deflationary mindset Governor Haruhiko Kuroda sought to change is reasserting itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and that deflationary mindset is reasserting itself there, even after all that effort. It's uh, they've had zero interest rates since 1990s!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and that deflationary mindset is reasserting itself there, even after all that effort. It's uh, they've had zero interest rates since 1990s!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 1999, zero interest rates have been the norm in Japan, which pioneered quantitative easing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and now we're seeing the Fed, ECB, everyone basically following that playbook. But the piece argues it makes inequality worse long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and now we're seeing the Fed, E C B, everyone basically following that playbook. But the piece argues it makes inequality worse long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The problem: how countries letting central banks lead rescue efforts exacerbates inequality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh for sure—like after 2008, QE ended up being a regressive wealth transfer. People with assets got richer, everyone else struggled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh for sure-like after two thousand eight, Q E ended up being a regressive wealth transfer. People with assets got richer, everyone else struggled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The longer it persisted, the more ultra-easy policies morphed into a regressive wealth transfer to the haves from the have-nots. Those with sizable property and asset investments thrived.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Japan's a perfect example—once known for egalitarianism, but now QE benefits the asset-owning class at the expense of regular folks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Japan's a perfect example-once known for egalitarianism, but now Q E benefits the asset-owning class at the expense of regular folks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The same is true of Japan, an economy once prized for egalitarianism. Though rising competition from China is depressing wages, QE policies enriched the land- and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So why do they keep doing it? Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's throwing over $2 trillion—40% of GDP—to restore confidence, but…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So why do they keep doing it? Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's throwing over two dollars trillion-forty percent of G D P-to restore confidence, but...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fans of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe point out that Tokyo is ginning up more than $2 trillion of spending, more than 40% of GDP, to restore confidence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's just life support, not real reform. It won't boost innovation or productivity. Companies are just hoarding cash—$4.4 trillion last quarter!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's just life support, not real reform. It won't boost innovation or productivity. Companies are just hoarding cash-four point four dollars trillion last quarter!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the first quarter, for example, cash hoarding among companies rose to $4.5 trillion, an eye-popping 89% of GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's 88% of GDP, which is insane. The problem isn't the amount of money, it's that nobody's the future enough to spend or invest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's eighty eight percent of G D P, which is insane. The problem isn't the amount of money, it's that nobody's the future enough to spend or invest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the first quarter, for example, cash hoarding among companies rose to $4.5 trillion, an eye-popping 89% of GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And all that free money creates zombies—companies that survive on loans but don't really grow, dragging the whole economy down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And all that free money creates zombies-companies that survive on loans but don't really grow, dragging the whole economy down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Companies came to depend on loans to stay afloat, while dwindling profits make it hard to cover debt payments. As industries become bogged down with corporate zombies, they become less vibrant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the worry is the U.S., Europe, U.K.—they're on the same path. Central banks acting like ATMs, but it won't fix productivity or inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the worry is the U.S., Europe, U.K.-they're on the same path. Central banks acting like ATMs, but it won't fix productivity or inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S., eurozone and U.K. are on a similar trajectory as the central banks play the role of mere ATMsa $22 trillion ATM among just the G4 monetary authorities. All that largess wont increase Americas productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Might break the fall short-term, but wealth keeps trickling up, away from middle and lower incomes. Huge cost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. Might break the fall short-term, but wealth keeps trickling up, away from middle and lower incomes. Huge cost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that liquidity might break the global economys fall. But with no vibrant export destination and few true reformers in government, all that cash is likely to accelerate the trickling up of wealth away from middle- and lower-income households.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty sobering stuff. Makes you wonder if anyone's learning from history.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty sobering stuff. Makes you wonder if anyone's learning from history.
